thread.title: Fans rev up for last Holden V8
thread.title_full: Fans rev up for last Holden V8

title: Fans rev up for last Holden V8
text:
Designer babies: Are we playing God? 21:56 PM Emily Moulton IT’S one of the biggest steps in human engineering that could eradicate genetic diseases. But is it a step too far? Fans rev up for last Holden V8 21:13 PM Joshua Dowling National Motoring Editor WE take the last locally-made Commodore SS for an exclusive first drive from its birthplace in Elizabeth to its spiritual home, Bathurst, ahead of the Great Race. Is Apple a cult? ‘It obviously is’ 20:24 PM Edgar Cervantes EVEN when working from a garage in the Silicon Valley, Apple co-founder Steve Jobs never saw his products as mere pieces of tech. He was seen as some form of tech prophet. Sony’s camera puts rivals in shade 20:11 PM Jennifer Dudley-Nicholson National Technology Editor SONY’s newest flagship smartphone, the Xperia Z5, boasts a camera that promises to deliver sharper photos faster than its Apple and Samsung rivals. The next big thing to take on iPhone 20:01 PM Harry Tucker THE mobile phone war is heating up more than ever, with Sony announcing the Australian release date and pricing of its three new models. The worst holiday picture you can take is of your boarding pass 19:24 PM HARRY TUCKER MOST of us are guilty of posting this picture before we go on a big holiday, but it just be the worst thing you upload. NASA’s huge news: ‘This world is alive’ 18:55 PM MATTHEW DUNN ONE of NASA’s main investigators has let slip the agency will be making another announcement, this time about Pluto. Fans rev up for the last Holden Commodore V8 October 8, 2015 8:41pm End of the line ... The new 2015 VF Series II SS-V Redline sedan. Joshua Dowling News Corp Australia Network Share Email a friend 
DIEHARD Holden fans have pushed sales of V8 Commodores to new heights two years before production is due to come to an end. 
More than one-third of all Commodores sold today is a V8, but that ratio is expected to increase as buyers get in before it’s too late and collectors snap them up to put away for keeps. 
The latest Commodore SS is powered by the same V8 that was once used by the Chevrolet Corvette, and Holden engineers fitted a “sound enhancer” to pump more of the V8 roar from the engine bay into the cabin. 
Holden has confirmed there will not be a V8 in the next generation 2018 Commodore, which is expected to be available only with four-cylinder or V6 power. 
Which is why News Corp Australia took the last of the breed on a symbolic journey from its birthplace — the end of the assembly line in Elizabeth — to its spiritual home, Mount Panorama, ahead of this weekend’s Bathurst 1000 race. The new 2015 VF Series II SS-V Redline sedan. Source: News Corp Australia 
The Holden Commodore has won 22 of the last 34 races on the mountain — more than any other car. 
The Commodore’s arch rival, the Ford Falcon, has only managed eight wins over the same period, and only 14 victories since the 1960s. 
But Ford has won the last two Bathurst 1000 races in a row and is aiming for a trifecta. 
Jim Richards, who co-drove with racing legend Peter Brock to give the Commodore its first Bathurst 1000 win — on debut in 1980 — said he is sad to see the end of an era. Craig Lowndes and Mark Skaife in their V8 Supercar Holden Commodore during the 2010 Bathurst 1000 at Mount Panorama in NSW. Source: News Limited 
“I think the Commodore helped keep GMH alive in Australia at various times,” says Richards. “You’ve got to remember there weren’t as many cars on the market back in those days as we have today. There were Ford families and Holden families. But now we’re spoiled for choice.” 
Holden V8 Supercar hero Mark Skaife says the end of Holden Commodore and Ford Falcon manufacturing in Australia within a couple of years is “a travesty”. 
“They are the best value rear-wheel-drive sedans in the world. But Australians today aren’t buying enough of them,” says Skaife. 
“The car market is too congested, there are too many models to choose from. But we won’t realise what we’re missing until they’re gone.” 
This reporter is on Twitter: @JoshuaDowling
